nodes.bodyText: Nit: would a switch be more reasonable than the huge if/else?
Haven't considered that, but these huge if/else are sort of everywhere, probably make sense to refactor them all in one diff if people agree.
There are other cases where we would need to refetch metadata. For example, LEADER_NOT_AVAILABLE. Another way we could handle this is to request an update any time we have partitions to retry.
I have to follow @ijuma suggestion to convert the check into a case switch, as the checkstyle won't let me merge 7 boolean statements XD
This is the new test being added, other changes are just side cleanup.
Since we're refactoring from if/else to a switch/case as well as changing the logic, it would be useful to include the before/after of errors that cause retry in the PR description
Sure, done!

This an awkward way to verify that the metadata gets updated. Nothing in the test actually involves the use of the new metadata. A more realistic scenario would be a leader change. Could we let the metadata update indicate a leader change and then use prepareResponseFrom to ensure that the retry goes to a particular node?

This test seems to pass with the original logic. I'm wondering if we need to let the offset request take two partitions. One of them can succeed and the other can fail due to the provided error so that we are handling the partial failure case.

I double checked, the reason was because the second try will not match the newLeader so that it actually disconnects and ask for a metadata update. I have injected a fatal error if the client reconnects to the original leader.

Ok, maybe we need a separate test for the partial failure case? I am interested in verifying 1) that metadata update gets triggered after a partial failure, and 2) the retry does not request partitions that were fetched successfully.
For 1), as long as it's partition level error, it's a partial failure. For 2) I could check to see if there is a way.
Not really sure this has value if the test case expects the leader change correctly.
Removed
Why construct this directly? Shouldn't we get it from the metadata update?
Unfortunately the metadata update happens within the offsetsForTimes call, so we could not capture it beforehand.
What I'm saying is that the metadata update contains the node we are looking for. So why do we need to build the Node object directly? e.g. where does 1970 come from?

Can we add an assertion like the following to ensure that both requests were sent?
            assertFalse(client.hasPendingResponses());
Add check of pending responses.
This is an interesting idea, but it seems good enough to verify the fetched offsets. The only way we could get 5L is fetching against the new leader.
In fact, it isn't. We shall hit a DisconnectedException first, and the fetcher would refresh the metadata before a third attempt. So a fatal exception is needed.
Ok. How about we use the NOT_LEADER error since that is the case we are trying to simulate?
Just did
Sounds good
